title: Uday Kiran
text:
Vajapeyajula Uday Kiran (26 June 1980 – 5 January 2014) was an Indian actor who primarily worked in the <a href="Telugu%20language">Telugu</a> films. His first three films, "<a href="Chitram">Chitram</a>", "<a href="Nuvvu%20Nenu">Nuvvu Nenu</a>" and "<a href="Manasantha%20Nuvve">Manasantha Nuvve</a>", were successful hits, earning him the title "Hat-trick Hero".
In 2001, he won the <a href="Filmfare%20Award%20for%20Best%20Actor%20-%20Telugu">Filmfare Award for Best Actor - Telugu</a> for the film "<a href="Nuvvu%20Nenu">Nuvvu Nenu</a>", and became the youngest winner of the <a href="Filmfare">Filmfare</a> best actor award after Tamil actor <a href="Kamal%20Haasan">Kamal Haasan</a>. In 2006, he made his <a href="Tamil%20cinema">Tamil</a> debut with the film "<a href="Poi%20%28film%29">Poi</a>", directed by veteran <a href="K.%20Balachander">K. Balachander</a>. Subsequently, he starred in romantic films including "<a href="Nee%20Sneham">Nee Sneham</a>" and "<a href="Kalusukovalani">Kalusukovalani</a>". His other performances have been in the films "<a href="Sreeram">Sreeram</a>", "<a href="Avunanna%20Kaadanna">Avunanna Kaadanna</a>", "<a href="Nuvvekaddunte%20Nenakkadunta">Nuvvekaddunte Nenakkadunta</a>" and "<a href="Jai%20Sriram">Jai Sriram</a>". Kiran died by suicide at his home in <a href="Hyderabad">Hyderabad</a> in January 2014.
Early life.
Vajapeyajula Uday Kiran was born in a <a href="brahmin">brahmin</a> familyon 26 June 1980 to VVK Murthy and Nirmala of <a href="Vijayawada">Vijayawada</a>. He did his schooling from K V Picket School and graduated from <a href="Wesley%20Degree%20College%2C%20Secunderabad">Wesley Degree College, Secunderabad</a>.
He had an older brother and has an older sister. His mother died when he was very young. Singer Parnika is his maternal cousin.
Career.
Kiran started modelling while he was in college. He made his film debut in the <a href="Hinglish">Hinglish</a> film "<a href="Mysterious%20Girl%20%28film%29">Mysterious Girl</a>" in 1999. In 2000, Kiran made his Telugu debut under his mentor, cinematographer turned film director <a href="Teja%20%28film%20director%29">Teja</a> with the film "<a href="Chitram">Chitram</a>", in which he played the 17-year-old lead character.
This film, followed by two other films, "<a href="Nuvvu%20Nenu">Nuvvu Nenu</a>" and "<a href="Manasantha%20Nuvve">Manasantha Nuvve</a>", made him among the very few actors in <a href="Telugu%20cinema">Telugu cinema</a> to deliver three consecutive successful films. His performance as a hot-blooded youngster in "Nuvvu Nenu" won him the <a href="Filmfare%20Best%20Actor%20Award%20%28Telugu%29">Filmfare Best Actor Award (Telugu)</a> in the year 2001.
In his fourth film, "<a href="Kalusukovalani">Kalusukovalani</a>", he displayed his dancing skills through the songs, "Udayinchina" and "Cheliya Cheliya". In his fifth film, "<a href="Sreeram">Sreeram</a>", he ventured into an action-oriented story of a youngster aspiring to become a top cop. 2002 saw him in "<a href="Nee%20Sneham">Nee Sneham</a>", another blockbuster movie of that year for which he was nominated for <a href="Filmfare%20Best%20Actor%20Award%20%28Telugu%29">Filmfare Best Actor Award (Telugu)</a> for the second time.
In 2005, he ventured into Tamil with the film "<a href="Poi%20%28film%29">Poi</a>" directed by <a href="K.%20Balachander">K. Balachander</a>. He then did two more films, "<a href="Vambu%20Sandai">Vambu Sandai</a>" and "<a href="Pen%20Singam">Pen Singam</a>" in <a href="Tamil%20language">Tamil</a>, the latter being the story penned by <a href="M.%20Karunanidhi">M. Karunanidhi</a>, which did moderately well at the box office.
Kiran last appeared in the 2013 film "<a href="Jai%20Sriram">Jai Sriram</a>". A reviewer from "<a href="The%20Times%20of%20India">The Times of India</a>" wrote, "From being a chubby lover boy with dimples showing on his cheeks to a man with muscles, Uday Kiran has metamorphosed as an actor. Such is his complete transformation that one is tempted to draw parallels to <a href="Nana%20Patekar">Nana Patekar</a>."
Personal life.
Kiran was engaged to <a href="Chiranjeevi">Chiranjeevi</a>'s daughter Sushmitha in 2003, but the engagement was called off. He married Vishitha on 24 October 2012.
Death.
Kiran died on 5 January 2014 by <a href="suicide%20by%20hanging">suicide by hanging</a> at his apartment in <a href="Srinagar%20colony">Srinagar colony</a>, Hyderabad. He was aged 33. No suicide note was found. The investigating <a href="Banjara%20Hills">Banjara Hills</a> police suspected financial problems to be cause and a case of suspicious death was registered. Kiran had suffered from depression due to financial crisis for almost a year.
On 6 January 2014, Kiran's body was kept at the Andhra Pradesh Film Chamber of Commerce and several film personalities including <a href="Dasari%20Narayana%20Rao">Dasari Narayana Rao</a>, <a href="D.%20Ramanaidu">D. Ramanaidu</a>, <a href="Venkatesh%20%28actor%29">Venkatesh</a>, <a href="D%20Suresh%20Babu">D Suresh Babu</a>, <a href="Meka%20Srikanth">Srikanth</a>, <a href="Shivaji">Shivaji</a>, <a href="Tanikella%20Bharani">Tanikella Bharani</a>, <a href="Chalapathi%20Rao">Chalapathi Rao</a>, <a href="Tammareddy%20Bharadwaja">Tammareddy Bharadwaja</a>, (ex) MLA <a href="Jaya%20Sudha">Jaya Sudha</a>, <a href="Paruchuri%20Gopala%20Krishna">Paruchuri Gopala Krishna</a>, <a href="Paruchuri%20Venkateswara%20Rao">Paruchuri Venkateswara Rao</a>, <a href="Shivaji%20Raja">Shivaji Raja</a>, <a href="Anup%20Rubens">Anup Rubens</a>, Samadra, Kadambari Kiran, <a href="Sunil%20%28actor%29">Sunil</a> and <a href="Anita%20Hassanandani">Anita</a> were among those who paid their last respects to the actor, before being taken to the cremation grounds. According to <a href="Andhra%20Pradesh%20Police">Andhra Pradesh Police</a>, a young fan of Kiran allegedly committed suicide by hanging himself from a tree at Komatapalli junction in Bobbili sub-division in Vizianagaram.
